TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed Improving Financial Access and Entrepreneurship Development Project  
will aim to expand the financial access and entrepreneurial capabilities of households and micro, 
small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) by strengthening financial intermediation in Papua 
New  Guinea  (PNG). 1 To  support  the  government’s  implementation  of  its  finance  sector 
development strategy and financial inclusion and small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) 
policies, the proposed project will help (i) improve the financial capacity, behaviors, and access  
of both men and women in households; (ii) improve the financial management and planning skills 
of MSMEs owned by both women and men, including MSMEs that develop and deploy solutions 
for health care; (iii) improve the business and product management capacity of participating 
financial institutions (PFIs); (iv) increase the use of digital financial services (DFS); and (v) 
strengthen the regulatory environment for microfinancing.2 
 
2.  The proposed project will continue ADB’s lead role in supporting greater financial inclusion 
in PNG through financial literacy programs and improving the capacity of microfinance institutions. 
It will address the very low levels of financial access in the population at large and among MSMEs 
that is weighing on entrepreneurship in a weakening economy and frustrates efforts to create jobs, 
raise incomes and reduce poverty. The project’s estimated $31.6 million cost is to be financed 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources by a regular loan of $15.0 million and a concessional loan 
of $15.0 million, as well as by counterpart funding equivalent to $1.6 million from the government, 
some of which will be in kind. All project procurement, disbursement, and the recruitment of 
consultants will be carried in line with ADB guidelines. 
  
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will be needed for project preparatory work to 
evaluate the approaches available, identify the appropriate implementation arrangements, and 
design the project properly. Many of the project’s subsequent activities will be based on this 
transaction TA study and analysis. The transaction TA will enable ADB to continue to consult 
relevant stakeholders up to and beyond the submission of the proposed project for ADB Board 
consideration, currently scheduled for the first quarter of 2021, and facilitate timely project start-
up. The transaction TA will also provide support alongside ongoing consultations with government 
counterparts that will be important to the effective delivery of the intended project outputs. The 
transaction TA is in PNG country operations business plan for 2020-2022.3  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  The transaction TA will support project-related diagnostic studies, including a finance 
sector assessment, economic and financial analysis, financial due diligence, a gender analysis 
and action plan, and the establishment of baseline data for monitoring. It will also enable the policy 
dialogue with the key stakeholders necessary to inform the preparation of a sound project design. 
The transaction TA will have 5 outputs.

5.   Through  these  5  outputs,  experts  will  help  in technical  assessments and  analysis, 
undertake  necessary  due  diligence  and  recommend  effective  design  and  implementation 
arrangements for the project outputs. The transaction TA outputs will: (i) undertake necessary 
due diligence to prepare the project; (ii) scope the required support for building financial and 
business development capabilities for individuals, households and MSMEs, with particular focus 
to support women and MSMEs in the health sector; (iii) determine, through due diligence of PFIs 
or consultations with PFIs where due diligence was recently undertaken, the potential areas of 
required support, including options to facilitate the delivery of the needed support; (iv) assess the 
opportunities to facilitate development of or expansion of innovative and gender sensitive DFS; 
and (v) facilitate improvements to gender sensitive financial inclusion data collection, analysis and 
reporting  to  establish  sex-disaggregated  baselines  and  enable  monitoring  of  the  relevant 
indicators.  
 
6.  Output 1: Due diligence to prepare the project completed. Due diligence will be 
conducted  to  help  prepare  the  project  and  determine  the  appropriateness  of  proposed 
interventions. Due diligence documents for processing will be prepared with support of the 
transaction TA. This will include a finance sector assessment, gender-sensitive economic and 
financial project analysis; financial due diligence, gender analysis and a gender action plan, and 
establishment of baseline data for monitoring. A finance sector assessment will help establish the 
sector’s key development needs by analyzing its strengths, constraints and weaknesses, risks, 
potential threats, and opportunities, including an assessment of MSMEs. Because the project will 
have no revenue stream, the gender-sensitive economic and financial analysis will assess project 
efficiency and the benefits the investment will bring to PNG and its local communities. The 
financial management of the Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG), the proposed executing and 
implementing agency, will be assessed through the financial due diligence. This will also include 
a financial evaluation of the project and an examination of the implementation arrangements. The 
transaction TA will support the gender analysis of the project, which is categorized as effective 
gender mainstreaming. A gender action plan will be prepared to help identify constraints on, 
needs for, and the priorities in the empowerment of women. The results will inform the project’s 
gender-inclusive output indicators and targets. 
 
7.  Due diligence and these assessments will make full use of documents and data based on 
the significant work already done by government in its development of financial inclusion and 
MSME-related policies and strategies, as well as technical reports prepared by the Pacific Private 
Sector Development Initiative.4 Available ADB templates will be followed to complete this output. 
The indicative deadline for delivering this output is November 2020. 
 
8.  Output  2:  Potential  areas  of  support  for  building  financial  and  business 
development capabilities of households and businesses identified. The financial literacy 
program delivered under ADB’s Microfinance Expansion Project will be reviewed under the 
transaction TA with a view to making any changes that will improve the proposed project’s training 
content or methods.5 The current financial literacy training in PNG will be examined, and the 
potential for the project’s collaboration and partnerships with the institutions now delivering them 
explored. The transaction TA supported study will seek to determine the best possible content to 
use and the best approaches to take in project activities aimed at enhancing the financial 
capabilities and behaviors of individuals, households and separately for MSMEs. Gender training

that focuses on household financial decision making will be considered. The forms of digital 
delivery most suited to literacy training and the availability of devices and the connectedness and 
know-how of household and MSME beneficiaries will also be considered, as will the possibility of 
providing appropriate enabling training. The transaction TA will be crucial in informing the design 
of effective training for the project, which must be based on sound sex-disaggregated analysis of 
capacities, constraints, preferences, priorities, and financial competency across a variety of age 
and income-level groups. 
 
9.  MSME-specific activities under the transaction TA will examine the training content and 
approaches required to build the capacity for better book-keeping, cash flow management, and 
financial planning in these businesses, as well as to further develop their entrepreneurship 
capacity.  Current  programs  will  be  reviewed  before  feasible,  effective  training  options  are 
identified to support the government’s objectives. Consideration will also be given under the 
transaction TA of possible ADB support to the BPNG for the establishment of a credit guarantee 
corporation under the BPNG SME Accelerator Program.6 MSMEs are also considered to be the 
origins of innovations in the health sector and with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the 
transaction TA will assess possible support to MSMEs to develop and deploy health care solutions 
in PNG. The indicative deadline for output 2 delivery is November 2020. 
 
10.  Output 3: Potential areas of support to participating financial institutions identified. 
The transaction TA will help determine and design the support selected PFIs will require from the 
project to improve the inclusiveness and quality of the financial services they provide. At least 
four PFIs will be consulted on their operations and the areas in which they could potentially benefit 
from project support.7 These four or more selected PFIs will be micro banks and savings and loan 
societies. Any support requested will be analyzed to determine how it could help improve access 
to financial services by MSMEs and households. The sustainable pathways for project support or 
reforms will be assessed, taking into account possible synergies with other ongoing work in the 
finance sector. Gender audits will be conducted of PFIs’ structures, processes, procedures, and 
policies to facilitate achievement of gender targets of the project. Due diligence on these PFIs will 
be undertaken wherever necessary.8 Options for improving PFI staff capacity during the project 
for delivering accessible, affordable, appropriate, and gender-sensitive financial services will be 
considered. Ways will also be sought under the transaction TA to improve the PFIs’ abilities in 
customer credit risk assessment, creating awareness of their financial services and products, 
providing customers with financial advice, and achieving a smooth roll-out of DFS. The indicative 
deadline for delivery of output 3 is November 2020. 
 
11.  Output 4: Opportunities to support innovative digital financial services identified. 
Possible areas of project support for improving DFS in PNG will be examined. The country’s 
current overall  DFS  agenda  will  be  analyzed before  feasible  intervention  opportunities  are 
identified.  Such  interventions  may  make  use  of  existing  or  planned  platforms  and  involve 
synergies with established concepts or pilot projects. The PFIs will be consulted to gain a clear 
understanding of their strategic directions on DFS, their willingness to pilot and introduce digital 
products and services for both men and women clients, and their related upcoming DFS needs. 
Obstacles to delivering physical financing services, limited connectivity, and PNG’s infrastructure

communities and people are scattered will be considered in assessing potential DFS solutions. 
The indicative deadline for the delivery of this output is November 2020. 
 
12.  Output 5: Strategies to streamline collection and management of financial inclusion 
data agreed. Deficiencies identified by a recent review in the financial inclusion data needed for 
the project’s sound design and monitoring will be addressed through the transaction TA. The 
collection and management of this data, which is used to inform the intervention policies, is 
undertaken by the Centre for Excellence in Financial Inclusion (CEFI). CEFI is also the primary 
driver of the financial inclusion agenda in PNG.9 The transaction TA activities will be guided by 
discussions with relevant stakeholders on the gathering and managing of sex-disaggregated 
financial inclusion data in PNG. The recommendations of the Financial Inclusion Data Analysis 
Project, which reviewed the collection and handling of financial inclusion data by CEFI and BPNG, 
will be followed up.10 Tools that can be used to collect and streamline sex-disaggregated data 
processing by CEFI, the BPNG, and the financial institutions will be identified and assessed. An 
evaluation  of  the  quality  and  appropriateness  of  the  existing  database  may  result  in 
recommendations for upgrades or changes. The relevant capacity-building needs including, data 
needs, sources, entry, analysis for decision making at the PFIs, CEFI, and the BPNG will be 
ascertained. The indicative deadline for the delivery of this output is November 2020.

for on-demand assignments, using the individual consultant selection method. Resource person 
contracts will also be considered for any immediate in-country support, including support for 
surveys and data collection. The requirements and lengths of the engagements will vary with the 
scope of work. The terms of reference for assignments by specialist consultants will be prepared 
by the lead consultants and submitted to the transaction TA supervising team for endorsement.

4.  The consultants are expected to work as one team and take an integrated approach to 
help develop the Improving Financial Access and Entrepreneurship Development Project for PNG 
under the leadership of the project officers. During transaction TA implementation, the consultants 
should (i) coordinate with ADB’s existing Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative, Phase IV; 
(ii) the Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (We-Fi); and other ongoing micro, small and 
medium enterprise development programs in PNG to avoid any duplication of efforts and explore 
collaborative opportunities under the project. 
 
5.  Qualification requirements and expected activities per contract are as follows: 
 
6.  Finance sector development expert (international, 9 person-months, intermittent). The 
expert will have a master’s degree in economics or finance, with strong knowledge of finance 
sector issues and challenges, financial technology solutions, institutional strengthening, micro-
banking, and capacity development―ideally developed and demonstrated through working with 
one of the major bilateral or multilateral programs, operating preferably in the Pacific. The expert 
will have demonstrated leadership skills and at least 15 years of relevant experience, of which 10 
years must be in program management within a development context. He or she will also have 
excellent communication and interpersonal skills to facilitate strong working relationships with 
PNG country officials and relevant stakeholders in a multicultural environment. The expert will 
have excellent analytical skills, proven ability to think strategically, identify and assess critical 
problems, and recommend workable solutions to stimulate finance sector development, and 
access to finance to households and businesses in PNG. The consultant must be willing and able 
to travel to PNG, as and when needed. The Finance sector development expert will: 
 
(i)  undertake a finance sector assessment for PNG, putting into perspective the sector’s 
contribution to PNG’s growth, and its importance to poverty reduction, and inclusiveness, 
and review strategies that support finance sector development in PNG and evaluate 
major issues that impede the growth and objectives of the finance sector, including 
identifying the underlying access to finance constraints, challenges, and risks to the 
sector, and potential areas of support under the proposed project; 
(ii)  identify gaps in finance sector regulation and policies that need to be addressed, and 
opportunities and strengths within the industry that can be further enhanced (taking into 
consideration the support provided under the previous project); review the Government 
of  PNG’s  financial  inclusion,  and  development  of  micro,  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises (MSMEs) policies and strategies to inform the finance sector assessment; 
(iii)  document and analyze the diverse range of finance sector support provided by the 
relevant  development  partners,  including  the  lessons  learnt  that  are  critical  to  the 
relevance, effectiveness, and impact of the proposed project. An Asian Development 
Bank finance sector assessment template will be used to complete this activity; 
(iv)  undertake economic and financial analysis for the proposed project by assessing the 
potential impact of, and economic and financial returns from the proposed project. This 
analysis will consider overall demand for financial services, and what portion of demand 
is  from  creditworthy  businesses  or  individuals,  further  improving  understanding  of 
constraints in accessing finance (considering both supply and demand sides). An Asian

Preparing Improving Financial Access and Entrepreneurship Development Project (TRTA 53097-002) 
Development  Bank  economic  and  financial analysis  template will  be  used to 
complete this activity;  
(v)  document other ongoing initiatives to improve access to finance in PNG, including the 
Pacific  Private  Sector  Development  Initiative,  Phase  IV  and  We-Fi  and  identify 
collaboration opportunities; 
(vi)  consult with micro-banks, and savings and loan societies to understand their operations, 
challenges with outreach and providing households and MSMEs with financial access, 
and discuss the potential areas of support that could be provided under the proposed 
project; 
(vii)  understand and evaluate the support requested by financial institutions to facilitate quality 
and inclusive access to financial services, determine practical channels through which 
the support can help improve access to and quality of financial services, and consider 
options through which the support can be delivered, including establishing a sustainable 
pathway for the proposed support or reform and possible synergies with other ongoing 
work in the finance sector; 
(viii)  contribute to selection of suitable institutions to support under the proposed project 
(participating  financial  institutions),  and  conduct  necessary  due  diligence,  including 
consulting financial institutions to identify possible areas where staff capacity needs to 
be improved, particularly with the increased uptake of digital financial services;  
(ix)  work with a data specialist to support streamlining of financial inclusion data gathering 
and analysis, and collection of reliable baseline data for the proposed project; and  
(x)  support  the  MSME  development  expert,  Financial  capacity  building  expert,  Digital 
financial  services  expert,  and  Gender  expert  to  develop  gender  sensitive  training 
programs  for  households  and  businesses  and  advance  the  digital  and  financial 
technology agenda in PNG. 
 
7.  Micro, small, medium-sized enterprise development expert (international, 9 person-
months, intermittent). The expert must have a degree in banking and finance with extensive 
knowledge on MSME sector development, enterprising, and agribusiness. The expert must have 
at least 12 years’ experience working with MSMEs, educating and training them and building their 
capacity for access to finance. Experience within a developing country context including, in the 
Pacific island is desirable. The ideal candidate will have technical expertise in creative research 
design, training businesses with financial management and book-keeping, and financial capability 
development. He or she will also have excellent communication and interpersonal skills to 
facilitate strong working relationships with development partners, PNG country officials and other 
stakeholders in a multicultural environment. The expert will have strong analytical skills and 
proven ability to think strategically, identify critical barriers to weak and limited MSMEs access to 
finance from formal financial institutions and propose practical solutions in the PNG context. The 
consultant  must  be  willing  and  able  to  travel  to  PNG,  as  and  when  needed.  The  MSME 
development expert will: 
 
(i)  review the Government of PNG’s MSMEs policies and strategies and understand the 
priorities, and work with MSMEs to analyze capacity, constraints, preferences, priorities, 
and challenges that needs to be addressed; 
(ii)  prepare realistic assessments about the situation of MSMEs in PNG, including analysis 
of  regulatory  frameworks,  access  to  finance  constraints  and  entrepreneurship 
development; identify the existing barriers and opportunities and provide appropriate 
recommendations that can be supported under the proposed project; 
(iii)  undertake an assessment of the MSMEs, including those involved in the health sector 
and identify ways through which support to MSMEs under the proposed project can

10   
contribute to cushioning the economic and social impact of COVID-19 and aid PNGs 
economic recovery; 
(iv)  work  with  relevant  institutions  or  stakeholders,  including  the  relevant  government 
ministries, civil society organizations, business associations, development partners, and 
any other associated bodies to understand and review the ongoing work around MSME 
development in PNG and propose interventions and collaboration opportunities, including 
supporting the Finance sector development expert assess and identify the financial tools 
and products necessary to ease MSMEs access to finance; and 
(v)  assess the existing financial capability of MSMEs in relation to the minimum requirements 
expected of clients of the micro-banks and savings and loans societies, and work with 
the Financial capacity building expert to scope the training content and approach required 
for building capacity in MSMEs for improved book-keeping, cash flow management, and 
financial planning; work with Digital financial services expert to identify digital means 
through which access to finance to MSMEs can be enhanced; and work with the Gender 
expert to assess the type of support that can be provided to women owned MSMEs.  
 
8.  Financial  management  expert  (international,  9  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
Financial management expert will have a degree in accounting, finance, or a related field, and will 
have a recognized professional accountancy qualification (Chartered Accountant and/or Certified 
Public Accountant). The expert should have at least 15 years (international consultant) experience, 
including in financial due diligence (FDD). The expert will conduct FDD in accordance with 
ADB’s requirements.12 The expert will also have excellent communication and interpersonal 
skills to facilitate strong working relationships with development partners, PNG country officials 
and other stakeholders in a multicultural environment. The consultant must be willing and able to 
travel to PNG, as and when needed. The Financial management expert will: 
 
(i)  conduct a financial management assessment of the executing/implementing agencies, 
including (a) assessing whether previous financial management assessments have been 
conducted by ADB or other agencies and, if so, reviewing the results and ascertaining 
whether these can be used as input, (b) assessing capacity for planning and budgeting, 
management  and  financial  accounting,  reporting,  auditing,  internal  controls,  and 
information systems (c) reviewing proposed disbursement and funds-flow arrangements, 
and (d) concluding on the financial management risk rating and identifying and confirming 
measures for addressing identified deficiencies; 
(ii)  support the preparation and agreement of cost estimates and a financing plan, which are 
based on verifiable data and are sufficient to support project implementation; 
(iii)  prepare  financial  projections  and  conduct  financial  analyses  of  the  executing  and 
implementing  agencies,  and  incremental  recurrent  costs,  to  determine  financial 
sustainability; 
(iv)  conduct financial evaluations (financial cost-benefit analyses); 
(v)  identify significant risks to project financial sustainability or viability, where necessary and 
propose  relevant  financial  performance  indicators  to  be  incorporated  in  financial 
covenants;  
(vi)  assess  and  reach  agreement  on financial  reporting,  auditing  and  public  disclosure 
arrangements for the project, and, as appropriate, identify and agree arrangements for 
receiving financial statements from executing and/or implementing agencies; and 
(vii)  conduct FDD of participating financial institutions, where necessary. 
 
 
 
12Relevant guidance is available at http://www.adb.org/projects/operations/financial-management- resources.

Preparing Improving Financial Access and Entrepreneurship Development Project (TRTA 53097-002) 
9.  Financial capacity building expert (international, 9 person-months, intermittent). The 
expert will identify appropriate content and facilitate design of financial literacy programs aimed 
at improving the financial capability of individuals and communities. The expert will also explore 
the possibility of introducing financial education in the national school curriculum. The expert must 
have a degree in education and/or training with knowledge on financial inclusion and capability. 
The expert will have at least 10 years of extensive experience in developing and implementing 
education and training programs in developing economies. Experience within the Pacific island is 
desirable. The ideal candidate will have technical expertise in creative research design, adult or 
community education, financial capability development, evaluation of financial behavior, and 
financial services and financial capability development models. He or she will also have excellent 
communication and interpersonal skills to facilitate strong working relationships with development 
partners, PNG country officials and other stakeholders in a multicultural environment. The expert 
will have strong analytical skills and proven ability to think strategically, identify critical barriers to 
weak and limited knowledge around personal and business finances and propose practical 
solutions in the PNG context. The consultant must be willing and able to travel to PNG, as and 
when needed. The Financial capacity building expert will: 
 
(i)  work  with  relevant  institutions  or  stakeholders,  including  the  relevant  government 
ministries, civil society organizations, development partners, and any other associated 
bodies to understand and review the ongoing work around financial literacy, retirement 
literacy, and financial capability in PNG and propose interventions and collaboration 
opportunities; 
(ii)  review  the  financial  literacy  program  delivered  under  the  preceding  Microfinance 
Expansion  Project  and recommend  options that  will  help  improve  the  content  and 
effectiveness of the program including, reaching out to economically active communities 
and identifying regions and provinces in need of financial capability trainings. The expert 
will work with individuals, and communities to analyze capacity, constraints, preferences, 
priorities, and financial competency across different ages, income levels, and genders, 
to determine appropriate training content and approach; 
(iii)  work with the MSME development expert to scope the training content and approach 
required  for  building  capacity  in  MSMEs  for  improved  book-keeping,  cash  flow 
management,  and  financial  planning.  The  expert  will  support  the  Finance  sector 
development expert assess the existing financial capability of households in relation to 
the minimum requirements expected of clients of the micro-banks and savings and loans 
societies (gap analysis); 
(iv)  develop  a  roadmap  for  households  identifying  their  path  towards  formal  economy, 
financial inclusion, and wealth accumulation while considering the access to finance 
challenges including, exploring cost effective means to deliver financial literacy and 
capacity building training, using digital technology given the wide dispersion of population 
in PNG; and 
(v)  identify feasible options with cost estimates to implement these programs under the 
proposed project, and work with the Pacific Financial Inclusion Programme, Bank of PNG, 
Ministry of Education, and the Provincial Governors to assess the options available to 
integrate financial education into the school curriculum.  
 
10.  Digital financial services expert (international, 8 person-months, intermittent). The 
expert  will  work  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  Senior  Digital  Technology  Specialist 
(Financial Technology Services) to identify feasible digital financial services (DFS) initiatives that 
can  be  supported  under  the  proposed  Improving  Financial  Access  and  Entrepreneurship 
Development project. The expert will have at least a master’s degree in information technology 
with expertise in international development, finance and economics. He or she must have at least

12   
12 years’ experience working across digital financial inclusion themes, including implementing 
digital  financial  strategies  and  policies,  developing  and  implementing  innovative  DFS,  and 
expanding the use of technology to increase access to financial services in developing countries. 
The expert will have strong analytical skills, in-depth understanding of business models behind 
payment  and  other  financial  instruments,  and  experience  in  innovative  payment 
mechanisms/financial services. Project design and management experience, including specific 
experience gained in developing countries and countries in transition, and demonstrable skills 
that  facilitate  technology-based  improvements  in  financial  infrastructures  will  be  highly 
considerable. Experience in the Pacific region and working and leading dialogue with public 
authorities for development and implementation of reforms in the area of DFS would be an added 
advantage. The expert will also have excellent communication and interpersonal skills to facilitate 
strong  working  relationships  with  development  partners,  PNG  country  officials  and  other 
stakeholders in a multicultural environment. The consultant must be willing and able to travel to 
PNG, as and when needed. The Digital financial services expert will: 
 
(i)  assess and analyze PNG’s overall digital agenda for financial services and help develop 
their digital strategy including, design thinking and future road mapping, and establishing 
the penetration of digital technology in PNG including, identifying barriers to increased 
use of DFS in the country; 
(ii)  identify digital tools that can be tailored to improve access to and uptake of financial 
services  for  the  unbanked  and  underserved  and  explore  possible  intervention 
opportunities to utilize existing or planned digital platforms including, possible synergies 
with ongoing concepts or pilots. The expert will support the Finance sector development 
expert to consult with financial institutions and understand their strategic directions on 
DFS and forthcoming needs including, willingness to pilot and introduce digital products 
and services; 
(iii)  understand and evaluate financial institution needs and propose effective options to 
expand DFS in PNG while considering challenges around wide dispersion of population 
and underdeveloped infrastructure within the country, including supporting the MSME 
development expert and consult with MSMEs to understand their financial services needs 
and suggest options how these can be delivered through the use of DFS, including 
analyzing active and feasible sectoral value chains that can be enhanced with DFS; 
(iv)  evaluate gaps in data governance and data management, review and strengthen the 
associated legal and regulatory frameworks, and assess and define the roles, processes 
and best practices an institution will follow to ensure the safety, quality and proper use of 
the data;  
(v)  support the Financial capacity building expert to explore and assess possible options to 
deliver  financial  literacy  training  through  digital  platforms,  including  assessing  the 
regulatory and supervisory gaps that need to be addressed to strengthen the DFS 
ecosystem in PNG, and capacity building needs for the Bank of PNG staff; and 
(vi)  facilitate the exchange of insights, experiences and technical expertise through hosted 
workshops, peer-to-peer exchanges, conferences and meetings within PNG. 
 
11.  Gender expert (international, 8 person-months, intermittent). The expert will work on 
increasing women's engagement in the finance sector, facilitating their move to the formal 
economy, and growing their businesses, where possible. The expert will be required to work with 
relevant institutions, ministries, agencies, and development partners to understand the challenges 
facing women’s access to finance in PNG and developing a feasible gender action plan that will 
be implemented under the proposed project. The expert will have an advanced degree in social 
science with at least 12 years’ experience working on gender specific issues, of which around 8 
years should be in small developing economies, preferably in the Pacific through an international

Preparing Improving Financial Access and Entrepreneurship Development Project (TRTA 53097-002) 
development organization. The expert will have extensive knowledge of institutional constraints 
faced by women in the Pacific, including legal and socio-cultural aspects. He or she will also have 
excellent communication and interpersonal skills to facilitate strong working relationships with 
development partners, PNG country officials and other stakeholders in a multicultural environment. 
The expert will have strong analytical skills and proven ability to think rationally in the Pacific 
context, identify opportunities to promote gender inclusive finance opportunities, and provide 
appropriate level of policy advice on gender issues in PNG. The expert must be willing and able 
to travel to PNG, as and when needed. The Gender expert will: 
 
(i)  consult with relevant institutions, ministries, agencies, development partners, community 
groups, and women-based organizations to understand the challenges facing women 
and women owned MSMEs access to finance in PNG; 
(ii)  undertake a gender analysis and develop a draft gender action plan considering the 
gender action plan from the preceding PNG Microfinance Expansion Project, and identify 
critical areas that continue to inhibit women’s economic empowerment in PNG, including 
limited access to finance and carry out detailed analytical assessments, informed by 
relevant data; 
(iii)  coordinate with government, development partners and other non-government agencies 
on  the  scope  of  ongoing  gender  initiatives  including  the  Women  Entrepreneurship 
Financing Initiative and the Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative; 
(iv)  collaborate with the Finance sector development expert, MSME development expert 
Financial capacity building expert, and Digital financial services expert to identify gender 
targeted programs and propose feasible approaches through which these initiatives can 
be effectively mainstreamed under each output of the proposed project; 
(v)  review the Gender Equity and Social Inclusion policy for financial institutions from the 
preceding PNG Microfinance Expansion Project, assess the status of its implementation 
with selected institutions, and hold discussions with micro-banks and savings and loan 
societies to assess their interest in further implementing the policy; and 
(vi)  devise  a  Gender  Equity  and  Social  Inclusion  policy  implementation  roadmap  and 
appropriate implementation plan for selected financial institutions including, developing a 
gender action plan for the proposed project with gender-inclusive design features, clear 
gender targets and monitoring indicators, and components to directly benefit women and 
girls. An Asian Development Bank gender action plan template will be used to 
complete this activity.
